STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
November 22, 2024
Annetra Bennett
Samaritas - Southeast
8131 E Jefferson Ave.
Detroit, MI, 48214-2610
Re: License #: CB820201265
SI #: 2024SIC0001751
Dear Ms. Bennett:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
Special Investigation #: 2024SIC0001751
Special Investigation Intake Date: September 9, 2024
License #: CB820201265
Licensee Group Organization: Samaritas
Licensee Designee: Laura Louise Mitchell Pflug
Chief Administrator: Annetra Jones
Agency Name: SAMARITAS - SOUTHEAST
Agency Address: 8131 E JEFFERSON AVE
DETROIT, MI 48214-2610
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 10/14/2025
II. METHODOLOGY
Contact Date Contact Method Contact Purpose
9/9/2024 6:26 PM Email Special Investigation Initiation
9/10/2024 1:38 PM Phone Interview
9/19/2024 9:47 AM Phone Interview
9/20/2024 4:27 PM Email Document received or sent
9/24/2024 7:05PM Documentation received or sent
9/29/2024 Phone Interview
9/29/2024 7:37 PM Documentation received or sent
10/1/2024 11:39 PM Documentation received or sent
10/9/2024 9:52 AM Phone Interview
10/9/2024 3:03 PM Phone Interview
10/14/2024 11:32 AM Email Documentation received or sent
III. INVESTIGATION
1

Rule Code Policy and procedures.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12202
Section (1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
Description procedures for all the areas of foster care services as provided in
R400.12203 to R 400.12214.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation For months there have been home visits in the caregiver's home
and no home visit sheets have been completed or signed.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant
On 9/19/2024 I interviewed Complainant by telephone. She
confirmed the information alleged in the complaint. She reported
home visit sheets are used by the agency workers related to
recording visits to the foster homes and the agency has not
completed them with her home in four or five months. She said
when workers visit they do not see the children alone or asks to
see the children bedrooms.
Chief Administrator
On 9/24/2024 I interviewed Chief Administrator (CA) by telephone.
CA reported it has been the agency’s practice for over 14 years to
complete home visits sheets for home visits. She reported workers
are required and expected to complete these sheets with the
foster parents/caregivers on monthly home visits. She reported
with the number of worker turnovers in recent years, this
expectation may have been impacted. She reported home visit
sheets are not uploaded to MISACWIS but are kept in the child’s
hard file. She was not certain as to whether home visit sheets
existed related to all monthly home visits for Child A’s and Child
B’s case which this complaint relates. She reported speaking with
the children’s foster parent, Parent C, on a number of occasions
and Foster Parent C did not report home visit sheets as a
concern.
CA reported there were performance issues with Child A and
Child B’s prior worker, Foster Care Worker (FCW) 2, and given
the worker changes, she suspected home visit sheets might have
been lacking. After checking on this matter, the CA provided
copies of two home visit sheets and acknowledged there were
only two completed in 2024. She reported FCW 1, and Foster
Supervisor (FCS) covered this case after FCW 2 was let go, and
FCS is covering the case now.
2

Foster Care Worker 1 (FCW)
On 10/9/2024 I interviewed FCW by telephone. She reported only
being assigned to Child A and Child B’s case for one month, from
July to August of this year. She reported going to the foster home
three to four times. She denied not seeing the children’s
bedrooms or not talking with them alone. She said only one of her
home visits was a monthly home visit, requiring a home visit
sheet. The other visits would have been for parent/child visits,
which took place via zoom at the foster home with her supervising.
She was not certain as to whether she had completed a home visit
sheet for the monthly home visit she completed on this case,
which she surmised would have been an August 2024 monthly
foster home visit. As for the parent/child visits she conducted FCW
reported Foster Parent C was aware no home visit sheets were
required for those.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS)
On 10/9/2024 I interviewed FCS by telephone. FCS reported
Child A and Child B’s case has been with the agency since 2020,
but the agency had the case prior in 2017 also. She said she was
only the supervisor on this case for about one month from
7/22/2024 to sometime in August 2024. She confirmed
information reported by FCW 1 related to her visit. FCS reported
prior to the July date the case was covered by FCW 2, who is no
longer with the agency, and the case was supervised by CA. She
said she began covering the case as the worker after Foster
Parent C continued to complain about the case and requested a
worker change. FCS said she completed a foster home visit in
September 2024, and she completed a home visit sheet. She said
FCW 1 would not have completed a home visit for September
2024. As for FCW 2’s home visit sheets. FCS reported not being
aware of those home visit sheets, that they are not documented,
and not in the children’s hard file. Nor are they to be stored there.
Reviewed
Child A and Child B’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
• Child A is a temporary court ward who was placed in his
current foster home on 9/22/2021.
• Monthly home visits occurred from 1/31/2024 2024 to
9/20/2024. And with the exception of a lack of detail about
the foster home visits on 6/15/2024 and 5/31/2024, home
visits show Child A and Child B were seen alone, and all
but those two showed the children’s rooms were viewed.
Three foster home visit sheets provided by CA related to home
visits for Child A and Child B in Foster Parent C’s home for
3

8/2/2024 and 9/20/2024. The latter, not the former show the foster
parent’s signature on the form. The 8/2/2024 sheet/home visit was
documented by FCW 1 and listed both Child A and Child B name
on the form. The 9/20/2024 home visits/ sheets were documented
by FCS, and one was for Child A and one for Child B respectively.
An additional home visit sheet for 10/4/2024 provided from and
completed by FCS for both children, and signed by Foster Parent
C.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed the evidence
supports a lack of compliance to the agency’s home visit sheet
documentation policy and violation of this rule.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Staff responsibilities.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all the following activities:
(b) Facilitating services and parenting time for children for
purposes of reunification.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The worker has not put in referrals for the biological parent’s
services.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant
On 9/19/2024 I interviewed Complainant by telephone. She
confirmed the information alleged in the complaint. She reported
the agency denied services to Child A’s birth father and did not
follow up with him for DNA testing. She reported the agency’s lack
of timely work to get services for the birth father has impacted the
permanency for both children. She said Foster Parent C asked for
FCW 1 to be taken off the children’s case, and the agency
replaced her with FCS. Foster Parent C has also asked to get
FCS taken off the case, but the agency won’t do it. She said the
agency is a mess on services. She said she has met with the
program director related to concerns, but CA has not met with her.
Chief Administrator (CA)
4

On 9/24/2024 I interviewed CA by telephone. CA reported FCW 1
and FCS are the only two staff who have had the case since mid-
July 2024. She said FCW 2 reported she had completed the
referrals on the biological parent back in April 2024. She said
FCW 2 also told Foster Parent C she had completed the referrals.
CA said they found out later that was not true, the referral was not
completed, and so they took action to try to get the services. CA
said there was a problem with referrals since the dad lived in
Genesee County. Also, for a significant time prior, the court had
delayed services for the dad, and getting the court order had been
a problem. She reported their agency is only responsible for
services to dad who is the parent to Child A.
CA reported there was not any physical documentation for
referrals for the children’s father because he resides in Genessee
county. She was going to have FCS write an email that detailed
dates, types of contacts (phone or emails) and person’s spoken
to, and for what services, and provide that to me related to this
matter. That documentation was provided by FCS on 10/14/2024
and is listed in the review section.
Foster Care Worker (FCW)
On 10/9/2024 I interviewed FCW 1 by telephone. FCW 1 reported
during her short time on this case from July to August 2024 she
solicited services for the birth father. She said the birth father
needed drug screens and anger management. She said she
started random drug screens on him on 8/6/2024. She reported
since the birth father resides in Genessee County a regular
Juvenile Assessment Center (JAC) referral through Wayne
County was not doable. She said she obtained a referral source
from the agency’s quality specialist, and she emailed that source
in Genesee County in an attempt to get the birth father registered
for services She said no one reached back out to her before the
case was transferred from her but she informed FCS of her email
to that referral source.
In terms of a psychological referral for the birth father, FCW 1
reported she spoke with the birth father about this at the end of
July 2024 and on 8/30/2024. The birth father told her in July he
already had an appointment scheduled for the psychological
assessment for 8/16/2024. She said on 8/14/2024 she asked the
birth father via text whether that appointment was still set for
8/16/2024. The birth father told her it was. When she spoke with
the birth father by telephone on 8/30/2024, he said he kept the
intake appointment on 8/16/2024 and an official first appointment
was pending for 9/5/2024. FCW 1 was not sure whether the birth
5

father kept the 9/5/2024 appointment. She said she had no further
knowledge of the case after its reassignment from her.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS)
On 10/9/2024 I interviewed FCS by telephone. FCS reported
Foster Parent C reported FCW 2 did not do things on the
children’s case. Foster Parent C reported the birth father needed
to be referred for services, but nothing specific. FCS reported
Foster Parent C’s concern about this case is that Foster Parent C
badly wants to adopt Child A and Child B.
FCS said FCW 2 never completed the referral for services for the
birth father, which would have been ordered before her
assignment to the case. She affirmed information reported by
FCW 1 as to services needed for the birth father. She also
reported the birth father actually did not follow through on that
psychological evaluation appointment. She said the last court
order from the hearing she attended on 9/27/2024 ordered a
psychological assessment. She said on 9/18/2024, she followed
up on FCW 1’s email requesting assistance with referring the birth
father for services in Genesee County, and no one has followed
up with her. She reported at this point, the agency is seeking to
obtain services for him via the JAC to see if they will service him
virtually.
Documents Reviewed:
Child A and Child B’s MISACWIS case record which showed
information as listed prior in this report, and parenting times for the
birth father.
Court Orders dating back to 2/26/2024 showing services for the
birth parents were to include a psychological evaluations, drug
and alcohol testing, anger management and parenting time.
A copy of an 8/24/2024 email from FCW to a service provider
indicating she has an order for a parent in need of anger
management services and would they please instruct her on how
to get this parent enrolled.
A copy of a 9/24/2024 email from FCS to a service provider
reaching out to register the birth father for parenting classes and
anger management and asking for assistance with the referral
process.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed the evidence
showed, though they are currently seeking to secure specific
6

services for the birth father now, the agency did not timely act to
refer, obtain, and facilitate those services for the birth father as
previously ordered by the court.
Conclusion Violation Established.
Rule Code Development of service plans.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418
Section (5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents and the
Description foster parents in the development of service plans to enable the
parent or parents and foster parents to understand the plan for the
child and the parents' and the foster parent's role in assisting the
agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to
and review the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or
parents and foster parents. The agency must inform the parent or
parents and foster parent that the information in the parent-agency
treatment plan and any other information about the child and the
child's family is confidential.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The case worker has let parent agency treatment plan
agreements (PATPA) lapse.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant
On 9/19/2024 I interviewed Complainant by telephone. She
confirmed the information alleged in the complaint. She said she
has only seen one PATPA (Parent Agency Treatment Plan
Agreement) in six months.
Chief Administrator (CA)
On 9/24/2024 I interviewed CA by telephone. CA reported this
allegation to be accurate, but that the foster parent had never
mentioned a lack of PATPAs as a concern. CA reported at the
time that FCS assumed case responsibility for the children’s case,
FCW 2 had left service plans and PATPAs undone. She said the
agency had been working to get these service plans up to date
since November 2023. She said the last report ended September
2024.
Foster Care Worker (FCW)
On 10/9/2024 I interviewed FCW 1 by telephone. She reported
completing one updated service plan during the month she was
assigned the children’s case. She said the service plan was one
month past due when she got the case. She said she never got a
7

PATPA signed by foster parent, because the service plan was not
approved prior to her being taken off the case.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS)
On 10/9/2024 I interviewed FCS by telephone. FCS reported
when she audited the case there was a service plan pending for
approval. She said the updated service plans (USP) for
12/5/2023-3/3/2024, 3/4/2024-6/1/2024 and 6/2/2024-8/30/2024
were completed, but were late. She said no USP came due while
she was assigned the case, but the one approved by the CA on
8/30/2024 and prior she received the foster parent’s signature on
9/20/2024.
Reviewed
Child A and Child B’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
• USP 9/6/2023-12/4/2023 was completed on 1/9/2024 and
approved by CA in MISACWIS on 6/20/2024. A PATPA is
not uploaded/signed by staff or the foster parent.
• USP 12/5/2024-3/3/2024 was completed on 7/18/2024 and
approved by CA in MISACWIS on 7/19/2024. The PATPA
was signed by CA for FCW 2, FCS and Foster Parent C on
9/20/2024.
• USP 3/4/2024-6/1/2024 was completed on 8/16/2024 and
approved by CA in MISACWIS on 8/30/2024. The PATPA
was signed by FCS, CA, and Foster Parent C on 9/20/2024
• USP 6/2/2024-8/30/2024 completed on 8/30/2024 and
approved by CA in MISAWCIS on 10/10/2024.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed the evidence
showed the service plans were not being developed or reviewed
with the foster parent and not all USP’s PATPA reported in this
report were signed by the foster parent or the signatures were
obtained after the receipt of this complaint.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED.
Rule Code Development of service plans.
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12418
Section (2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
Description and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at least
once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Violation Additional findings.
Type
Allegation Updated service plans were not completed timely.
8

Investigation Interviews:
The CA, FCW 1 and FCS were interviewed by me via telephone
on 9/24/2024, 10/9/2024, and 10/9/2024 respectively. Each of
them reported the prior worker, FCW 2, had USPs she had not
completed timely.
Reviewed
Child A and Child B’s MISACWIS case record which showed:
• USP 9/6/2023-12/4/2023 was completed late on 1/9/2024
and approved by CA in MISACWIS on 6/20/2024.
• USP 12/5/2024-3/3/2034 was completed late on 7/18/2024
and approved by CA in MISACWIS on 7/19/2024.
• USP 3/4/2024 -6/1/2024 was completed late on 8/16/2024
and approved by CA in MISACWIS on 8/30/2024.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed the evidence
showed the service plans were not completed timely.
Repeat Violation Established
Renewal 2024, CAP Approved 10/12/2023
Conclusion REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A corrective action plan is required.
November 13, 2024
___________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
November 21, 2024
